Privacy Coins

Open thread • Replies: 53 • Updated: 2026-02-17 09:43 UTC

OP

Whether you like it or not, BTC is dying. Which way anons?

Early replies (first 3)

61849481
Gold and silver.

61849898
>>61849447
XMR as always.

>>61849481
Acceptable but unusable for internet transactions and too easily stolen. Also makes smaller or spontaneous transactions harder unless the governments were to issue gold coins again and that would be bearish.

61849958
>>61849447
>BTC is a pedo coin
>most used currency for CP is not however
quit the infighting, monegro.

61856605

No, it's not similar at all. The arches of the M are completely different.
The chrome symbol is the divine king symbol and matches exactly, and you can see far more similarities between the tubal Cain and facebook logos.
This meme sucks, the discord you got it from sucks, your ability to evaluate schizo levels suck, and you suck.

>You claim that you were browsing the general but you haven't seen the main topic of the last few generals? Just admit that you're wrong.
I hate talking to retarded bots. Admit that Im wrong about what exactly? that your entire thread glows to high heaven or that you "main topic" is non existant across the first 3 maxed out posts of general info?

>bot continues to talk about how its far more unlikely for anons BTC to be stolen via address poisoning than for someone to pick his locks and steal his gold. Bots are coded by jeets, transfolk, and der jude, none of which are qualified to write bots.
How unfortunate.

>epstein files show he not only met with moot from 4chan, but also conspired to start /pol/, and had his hands in the israeli team that began to work on bitcoins code.

l knew if i waited Iong enough, the bot wouId show. You cant foIIow any post and its repIies worth a damn. ldk why you keep bring up the same shit spamming it everywhere. l wish jannies wouId range ban your ass.

Tried Bisq, but hardly any sellers and also a risk of your bank account getting flagged / closed if the person is dodgy.

Any other digital asset is traceable.

You have 1 (one) more opportunity for an early Bitcoin moment.

Monero will be the world currency of the 2030s and beyond.

on the XMR thread, this is the same bot>>61860201 DXIC7i+b
it just goes on and on. hope real anons find this post and start to question wtf is going on around here.

61862542
>>61862475
Do you have Revolut?

Use it on Hodlhodl (trade escrow service)
Send it to some BTC wallet (Sparrow)
Use Trocador to convert it to XMR

61862551
>>61859002
Privacy is basically impossible to do for smart contracts outside of creating a specific app such as Tornado. When you create specific apps such as Tornado, you make it extremely vulnerable to censorship from the government, like happened to Tornado. Even though the lawsuit was "dropped", activity on Tornado is basically nonexistent because nobody trusts it anymore. They shouldn't. Likewise, nobody should ever trust a "privacy app" on top of a public L1.

And don't get me started on how ridiculous a "privacy L2" would be on top of a public L1.

If you want privacy, you start at the L1 layer.
If you want privacy, you choose Monero.

>See a $600 receipt for perfume and makeup, and a bank note evidencing a $1800 transfer to her neet sister who also has 2 neet sons and a neet daughter.
>Dad gambled away another $10K in stocks.
>He keeps sending me job openings in other states/cities that require 10+ years of experience and he tells me "just walk up to them and ask them to train you, that's how we did it back in the old days"
>My own savings are slowly dwindling and I've got no more than a few months left before I'm officially broke
>800+ job apps and nothing yet
I'm not sure how much more of this I can take bros...
Why won't the economy get better?
Who do I blame for this miserable situation?
What are some easy painless ways to check out of this economy earlier don't speak?

It really isn't. You can live VERY cheaply in a lot of Asian countries (Thailand, Laos, Indonesia) and do ridiculously low-paying remote work and still come out with net savings every month.

I worked in Taiwan (DON'T GO THERE) for a while and was able to save over 50% of my pay even though I made half as much as an American would make doing the same job (not ESLosering).

Wish I hadn't because it completely destroyed my health permanently (they're just as bad, maybe worse, about dumping toxic industrial chemicals in food as the mainland chinsects), but it was the only thing available to me after the 2008-12 crash during the Obamaconomy.

anything else while we have the magic wand out sir?

61860705
>>61859951
>How the fuck do you reach the conclusion that America needs an "international order" to function when it's downfall has correlated perfectly to its kowtowing to international interests
What international interests? The US has been profiting off the international order since Breton Woods. Its rise as a superpower correlates to the dollar’s international dominance. It’s the opposite of what you’re describing.
>America is almost entirely self-sufficient
It is completely dependent on foreign pharmaceuticals and various input goods for manufacturing. It has virtually no domestic source of lithium, cobalt, graphite or REMs.
>the problem is international Jewry and this will be rectified when the us becomes an autarky
Why?

The rotting elephant in the room is a declining dollar, obscene debt, and an overinflated market + made up statistics. None of this gets better by fucking up international trade.

61860719
>>61857750

US being in a recession isn't about Trump.
Yes he's a fucking retarded boomer brained moron, but US has been doomed to hit this point sooner or later ever since they decided to crank the money printers on permanently after 2008 and doomed the entire West to be stuck in a slow death limbo.
Everyone has basically just been waiting for the big one for years now and we're getting closer and closer to it.

61860738
>>61859951
You have no idea how the dollar system works and it shows. What's happening to the United States right now is irreversible

61860813
>>61860719
Printing after 2008 happened because 2008 happened, which happened because republicans deregulated finance. You're right, it's not about Trump, it's about half the country being fucking retarded hicks

61860867
>>61860813
Republicans like Raegan deregulated finance, that’s true (though some of that was put into motion by Jimmy Carter). That said, it’s impossible to talk about 2008 without recognizing that Clinton is the one who repealed the Glass-Steagall act and let insurance banking merge with commercial banking. Pretty much every president for the 30 years leading up to 2008 did something to enable it or make it worse.

61860880
>>61860867
I forgot that Clinton was also the one that made derivatives immune to regulation. He really fucked up finance.

61860916
>>61857825
Holy shit this is the most retarded post I have ever read on /biz/, why are you on a finance board??

61860980
>>61860880
Clinton also forced banks to give mortgages to people with bad credit scores and low income

61861063
>>61857508

GDP was never meant to measure the health of the economy. Simon Kuznets advised against using it for that purpose.

61861445
>>61860705
>It has virtually no domestic source of lithium, cobalt, graphite or REMs.
There are actually fucking tons of sources, but none of them are developed because US companies exported the environmental cost of mining them to "dEvElOpInG" nations for cheaper labor/materials and most of the mines shut down because they couldn't compete. There are ludicrous amounts of these materials just sitting there in the US.

The US could be self-sufficient (example: fracking boom was because oil price had gotten to the point where domestic supply was economically viable again - in less than a decade the US had more oil than it could even use, because the oil was already in the ground, just not being extracted), but the profit motive won't allow self-sufficiency to persist if it's cheaper to import.

61861531
>>61861445
>”we are almost entirely self-sufficient”
>”ok we currently have no infrastructure to mine these resources”
Yes, exactly. We are totally dependent on foreign suppliers and as of right now we do not have a domestic source for these things. My point stands and yours is wrong. Coping about how we COULD have these things eventually doesn’t matter. Like it or not, the US is not self-sufficient, and it isn’t close. We import tremendous amounts of goods. Don’t even bother looking into pharmaceuticals because it will just depress you.

61861694
>>61857750
We've been in a recession since 2023. This isn't glorphf's fault or joepedo. Our economy is fake and gay made up of jewish daycare bullshit jobs. Soon it will all unravel.

61861711
>>61861531

A water source is still there even if nobody builds a well. Since you seem to get that, you were probably looking for the phrase "domestic SUPPLY."

item.title: stock market: allocation and frequency — 13 replies — 28.7/hr
item.content:encoded:
stock market: allocation and frequency

Open thread • Replies: 13 • Updated: 2026-02-17 09:39 UTC

OP

Am I insane foe wanting to invest in 50 different comapnies and 3 ETFs? Am I overdoing it? Or should i just choose sector ETFs instead of companies to reduce my list.

Also how often should I invest per year to reduce overall commission costs? Quarterly? Is there a way on IBKR to place a basket order so I only pay for one trade across multiple stocks?

Early replies (first 3)

61862142
50 is too much, portfolio theory says around 20-30 before it's not worth it and I would lean towards the smaller number

61862144
>>61862099
In general it's better to bet on something broader than something more specific. As long as the sector grows you'll grow but a company can easily fail even if the product or the sector is wanted. When I was younger I invested in Nikola because I thought I would be hedging against Tesla. Turns out the company was a mess and people don't care that they're sucked dry by Elon. I still believe EVs will be more important for long haul and business use.

61862220
>>61862144
>I invested in Nikola because I thought I would be hedging against Tesla. Turns out the company was a mess and people don't care that they're sucked dry by Elon
you thought the ceo who would go on to lead tsla to a 20x was sucking they company dry so instead you put your money into an obvious scam whose CEO would go on to be arrested for securities and wire fraud? Where do you do your research, the daily show???

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61862273
Translation:
>PLEASE GOD STOP DUMPING MICROSOFT AHHHHHHHH

61862287
>>61862142
Why?

61862313
>>61862099
https://investcalc.github.io/

61862329
>>61862220
>you thought the ceo who would go on to lead tsla to a 20x was sucking they company dry
No stop trying to twist the words on my screen. Elon is milking his customer base and its obvious and apparent to everyone. I thought people would notice that and move to a better car manufacturer.
>whose CEO would go on to be arrested for securities and wire fraud?
Hindsight is 20/20
>Where do you do your research, the daily show???
I invested long before any of the scandals came to be and the focus on long haul makes sense for as long as we don't have a sufficient hydrogen infrastructure.

61862353
>>61862099
Can he take one picture where he doesn't look like a slimeball piece of shit? Just one.

61862425
>>61862287
MPT claims you can only diversify away idiosyncratic (company specific) risk, and at some point you have so many different companies and exposure to so many different sectors that adding another company doesn't reduce risk by much if at all. I think markowitz or sharpe has a mathematical proof on it out there somewhere. Apparently they say that number is around 20-30
I say lean towards less because you have to take into consideration transaction costs and time and energy spent reorganizing your portfolio and tracking your positions as well. If you're just an average person and not a portfolio manager getting paid you're probably just fine with 12-15

61862458
>>61862099
the idea of diversifying is reducing the volatility of your portfolio value, if you want to do it properly you should study the correlations between your picks, this has a cost of reducing the potential gains but they become more steady. For example if you pick 50 tech companies and etfs and the ai bubble bursts, the stocks are so highly correlated between them that all of them would go down at the same time and diversifying would be useless, even if between your picks you picked the one tech company that survives

61864023
My strategy was to invest in a new company every month
Guess I'm retarded...

61864325
>>61864023
>The average diversified portfolio holds between 20 and 30 stocks, but could have even more. The Motley Fool's position is that investors should own 25 or more different stocks. Diversifying your portfolio in the stock market is a good idea for investors because it decreases risk by ensuring that no single company has too much influence over the value of your holdings.

61864389
>>61862099
You will have the slowest and most ass returns.
Only do this if you are interested in your retirement situation.

61863529
>>61862922
What is it with China and India where people's deaths are just so much less consequential?

This is a horrifying death but it's also so stupid, everything about it is stupid, from the motorcyclist trying to pass in the shoulder of the roadway at 90mph to the retard taking an achingly slow turn off a busy thoroughfare without a turn signal (when he easily could've just pulled in and turns in half the time) to the car behind the slow retard switching lanes on a dime due to the retard in front of him...

I know it's tragic, but when you watch the video, the whole thing feels like nobody there is sentient. In White societies every death feels like a casualty that needs to be reported on in the news, obituary read, family mourns. In asian societies every death feels like an ant got stepped on by an elephant in a rain forest, just totally inconsequential, the machine keeps on going. It's uncanny.

i've been to the world computer summit in june last year and i've talked to anyone in the team that i came across. let me tell you one thing; they're comfortable. they all get hundreds of thousands in salaries each year and could not care less about the price. at the event there were two very clear very seperate pockets. the VC's and the (((COMMUNITY))) and you could see the disgust in the eyes of the VC's for the community. any questions regarding tech or details to the team were answered dismissively, there is not an ounce of passion present in the entire team. i think all they care about is doing research on cryptography.

i've met the guy from openchat and he looked like he hadn't slept a full 8h in several weeks, he looked anxious and stressed.
when talking to the community members i've probed for interesting projects, and literally the best project present was windoge98.
after that dominic played with an llm on stage for an hour straight everyone pretended it's the second coming of steve jobs.
